title: Building a digital democratic platform designed for civic matters
text:
Building a digital democratic platform designed for civic matters

A great time to innovate democracy, while the technology is inÂ place.

About twenty years ago, just after turning eighteen, I tried to follow politics because I cared about living in a fair society. I wanted everyone to have food, healthcare, safety, educationâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe basics any decent person wishes for others. But politics felt toxic: shouting, accusations, and no real progress. Even the word began to feelÂ heavy.

I know Iâ€™m not alone; many people feel frustrated or disconnected. Yet politics should be nobleâ€Šâ€”â€Šcollaboration, empathy, coexistence.

So Iâ€™m writing this to explore how technology and digital design might help us rebuild that connection and make democracy feel humanÂ again.

The bad side of politics and technology

Itâ€™s almost impossible to separate politics from technology today. Every major shift in communication has reshaped how we organise, argue, and imagine our future. New tools always begin as freedomâ€Šâ€”â€Šmore voices, more access, more possibilityâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut over time they start shaping us in ways we barely notice. Social media felt like a new democracy at first, until algorithms pushed us into echo chambers, doom scrolling and trained us to react instead of reflect. Technology can amplify empathy or anger, truth or distortion. It depends on how we design it. If we build tools that reward curiosity over conflict, politics could start to feel humanÂ again.

Propaganda isnâ€™t new, but technology has made it faster, more precise, and far more personal. In the past, newspapers and radio spread broad, one-size-fits-all messages. Today, algorithms whisper tailored narratives to each of us. The Cambridge Analytica scandal highlighted how personal data can influence political persuasion, but similar patterns have also been observed in Europe. Ahead of the 2024 EU elections, researchers uncovered coordinated disinformation networks operating across France, Germany, and Italy, using fake accounts to quietly influence voter perception. This is the new propaganda: subtle, targeted, and often unnoticedâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot designed to inform us, but to keep us engaged and predictable.

If we want more harmonious communities, we must rebuild respect, trust, and understanding. This isnâ€™t just about better appsâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about better values. A healthy digital political system rests on a few core principles: a thirst for truth over partisanship; transparency by default in decisions and algorithms; effectiveness in solving real problems; equal access to voice regardless of power; and truth before speed, prioritising accuracy over virality. It also requires agility, allowing nuanced positions; holism, showing how issues connect; simplicity, making participation approachable; and decentralised ownership to prevent concentrated control. These values must guide the technology we designÂ next.

Designing a Political Platform That Supports Equilibrium

A fictional glimpse of this future appears in N. A. Turnerâ€™s short story â€œThe Democr App.â€ In it, society runs on constant digital referendums, with citizens voting directly on everything from climate policy to economic reform. Turner captures the tension at the heart of radical digital democracy through one of his characters:

Mouse87 still wondered if the majority could decide what is true and just for the entire nation. Could the people govern themselves? He believed they could. He had to. It was part of his designâ€¦ to unite people, to let democracy shine in its truest form. But he made one mistake. Mouse87 wanted people to become equal, but no two persons are the same, let alone a wholeÂ nation.

This fictional moment reveals a real-world challenge: if technology is going to serve democracy, it must be built for equilibrium, not engagementâ€Šâ€”â€Šhelping people understand before they react, listen before they judge, and collaborate before theyÂ divide.

Imagine a platform where political discussion doesnâ€™t lead to outrage or exhaustion, but to clarity. Instead of a chaotic feed, citizens move through a guided process that adds context, shows diverse perspectives, and explains how each decision touches real life. Every issue is presented holistically: the problem, public feelings, solutions, supporters, opposers, risks, and consequences. The platform wouldnâ€™t punish disagreement; it would encourage informed disagreement.

The biggest risk to be addressed is that people are emotional thinkers. We rely on shortcuts, familiar ideas, and content that feels good. That makes building a political platform for understandingâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot reactionâ€Šâ€”â€Šuniquely challenging. Echo chambers can quietly return. Misinformation spreads fast. Power can be centralised. People get overwhelmed or tune out. Privacy must be protected. Algorithms can inherit cultural bias. And cynicism can make citizens feel their participation doesnâ€™t matter. These risks arenâ€™t technicalâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re human. The goal isnâ€™t perfection but transparency, safety, and adaptability, designing for how people actually think while gently helping them grow toward deeper, fairer public understanding.

Proposal

I propose to build a digital democratic platform designed for civic matters. A space where citizens explore issues through context, clarity, and diverse perspectives. The proposed solution is inspired by a collection of technologies and methodologies that already exist in theÂ market.

Modernising the democratic process

Modern democracies could learn from how product teams build great systems: through continuous cycles of learning, testing, and improvement. In tech, decisions arenâ€™t finalâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re iterated. After research, prototyping, and alignment, products launch, are monitored, refined, and improvedÂ again.

Our political systems rarely work this way. Voting is treated as the end of the process, not the beginning of a learning loop. Imagine instead a democratic cycle that mirrors product development: collect facts, collect peopleâ€™s feelings, ideate, vote, enforce and monitor, then learn and iterate. Decisions would become living processes, shaped by data, experience, and citizen feedback.

This concept is not only mine to share; the minister of the digital affairs of Taiwan, Audrey Tang, explained with some major wins in his announcement.

https://medium.com/media/378431ed5045273f32d50ae23e346c34/href

Modernising democratic roles

Modernising democracy also means modernising our roles within it. A healthier system depends on shared participation, not hierarchy

  • Citizensâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStay curious, seek holistic truth, and engage respectfully with the community. Understanding comes beforeÂ opinion.
  • Representatives & Expertsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStudy issues deeply, gather reliable evidence, and communicate clearly. Their role is to guide, notÂ rule.
  • Journalists & Communicatorsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGo beyond reporting outcomes. Explain processes, challenge assumptions, and make complex information accessible and accurate.
  • Moderators & Facilitatorsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠEnsure discussions remain constructive, inclusive, and fact-based. Conversations need care, notÂ control

Getting inspired by existingÂ tools

This proposal isnâ€™t built from scratch; it stands on the shoulders of platforms already pushing civic understanding forward. Across the world, tools from deliberation to fact-checking show how technology can reduce bias, reveal context, and support healthier public dialogue. Below are the key inspirations:

https://medium.com/media/287411905cf22ca0843b2f5dbdd50386/href

Platform Features

Civilian Contributions

This is the heart of the platformâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe civilian contributions, or what we usually call posts. Every user can contribute something meaningful: an idea, a problem, an opinion, a question, or even an opportunity for improvement. Contributions can be connected to existing topics or open entirely newÂ ones.

But here, itâ€™s not just what you say that mattersâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s how you say it.
The platformâ€™s goal is to guide users toward expressing ideas in a fair, respectful, and inclusive way, helping people frame their thoughts with clarity and empathy. The tone should promote understanding, not hostility.

When creating a post, the system gently assists the user in identifying who might be affectedâ€Šâ€”â€Šboth positively and negativelyâ€Šâ€”â€Šand what risks or consequences the idea might carry. This helps transform a simple complaint or reaction into a civic contributionâ€Šâ€”â€Ša statement grounded in awareness and responsibility.

Example:

  • Initial Post:
    â€œIt was about time for an accident. Our roadsÂ suck!â€
  • Guided Contribution:
    â€œAfter the accident last week on James Bond Street, Iâ€™ve noticed how poor visibility is around that area. I completely understand the need to illuminate archaeological monuments beautifully, but perhaps we can adjust the lighting design to make the road safer for drivers and pedestrians.â€

Engaging With Contributions

Once a post is shared, the conversation truly begins. Engagement on this platform isnâ€™t about collecting likesâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about building knowledge together. Users can interact with a post by adding further research, supporting documents, related ideas, or personal experiences that enrich the discussion. Reactions are not noise; they are part of the learning process. Every contribution adds a layer of understanding to the originalÂ idea.

As discussions grow, the system detects when a post gains meaningful tractionâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot through volume, but through depth, balance, and constructive participation.

For example, imagine the earlier post about the James Bond Street accident. As others contributeâ€Šâ€”â€Ša local architect sharing a visibility report, a cyclist uploading a nighttime video, a city planner linking to safety regulationsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe post evolves into a valuable public thread. The system may then elevate it to the top of the #Transportation section, where local authorities, journalists, or experts can see itÂ easily.

Contributing to engagements becomes a path to collaboration, connecting citizens, experts, and decision-makers around the same livingÂ issue.

Feedback, Evaluation, and Reporting Layer

Every contribution can be evaluated by the community through a structured feedback model. Instead of quick reactions, users can mark a post as helpful, insightful, unclear, or biased. They can also add short notes explaining whyâ€Šâ€”â€Šoffering specific, respectful observations rather than emotional responses.

Take the example of the James Bond Street accident post. As the discussion grows, others might respond likeÂ this:

  • â€œHelpfulâ€Šâ€”â€Šthis identifies a recurring safety issue and offers context.â€
  • â€œUnclearâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s not clear who manages street lighting in that zone; can you clarify?â€
  • â€œInsightfulâ€Šâ€”â€Šlinking the lighting to archaeological site preservation adds an interesting angle.â€

This structured feedback system evaluates quality, not popularity. Thoughtful, diverse responses elevate a post; unclear ones prompt clarification or community notes. Citizens can flag misinformation or harm, triggering contextual reviews rather than punishment. Over time, this two-way process teaches users to communicate better and helps the platform highlight substance overÂ outrage.

Enhanced Community Notes

Community Notes has proven that context builds trust. When users add explanations instead of blunt â€œmisleadingâ€ labels, people are more likely to believe the correction and share less misinformation. A study published by Oxford University Press found that contextual notes were significantly more trusted than standard misinformation flags.

A University of California, San Diego analysis confirmed that Community Notes were highly accurate and credible, especially for vaccine-related posts. Similarly, research on arXiv reported that when a note is attached to a misleading post, engagement drops sharplyâ€Šâ€”â€Šreposts by ~45% and likes byÂ ~43%.

Still, the model struggles with speed, diversity, and visibility.
Many viral posts never receive notes in time, and a small group of contributors writes the majority. This pattern was noted in a large-scale data transparency report and in follow-up analyses on Wikipedia.

Because the platform isnâ€™t optimised for speed or emotional reactions, each post is first shared with a segment of users who have expertise in that topic. This allows knowledgeable contributors to add early context and Community Notes. If the post begins gaining traction, a community review mode activates, inviting a wider and more diverse group of users to contribute additional context before the content spreadsÂ further.

All notes appear directly within the post, with the systemâ€™s LLM providing clear, neutral summaries.

Algorithm for Understanding

Most digital platforms today are built around one metricâ€Šâ€”â€Šengagement. Their algorithms are designed to maximise emotion, outrage, and addictive scrolling, because the longer we stay online, the more ads we see, and the more profitable the systemÂ becomes.

Our platform must take the opposite path. Instead of optimising for emotion, it optimises for understanding. Instead of amplifying what divides, it surfaces what connects.

The algorithmâ€™s purpose is to guide comprehension. It promotes content that helps people see the full picture, not just the side that fits theirÂ bias.

Algorithm key principles:

1. Relevance First
Content is served to the people who can meaningfully enrich it: citizens directly affected, experts with relevant insight, and communities equipped to help. This creates deeper engagement, allowing posts to gather context, sources, impacts, and risksâ€Šâ€”â€Šrather than shallow reactions or fragments.

2. Exposure to Multiple Viewpoints
The system deliberately broadens perspectives. It resurfaces skipped materials, introduces contrasting views, and reduces the blind spots that create echo chambers.

3. Promote Thoughtful contributions
Thoughtful contributions are highlighted above heated or repetitive ones, shifting the culture from reaction to reflection. This slows the rush toward instant opinions and encourages users to pause, explore context, and consider alternative viewpoints before responding.

Join Discussion Rooms

When a topic gains traction and enough information is gathered, it can evolve into a virtual discussion roomâ€Šâ€”â€Šan open dialogue space where citizens, experts, and representatives come together to exchange ideas in realÂ time.

Because these discussions are hosted within the platform, all previously gathered data helps structure the meeting through dedicated moderator tools. Insights generated during the session are then fed back into the platform, enriching the topicâ€™s knowledge base and improving the ongoing civicÂ process.

Each session is moderated by a certified facilitator from the platformâ€™s community, whose role is to ensure inclusivity, respect, and focus. After the discussion ends, participants can rate the moderatorâ€™s fairness and clarity, creating a transparent feedback loop that strengthens future sessions.

Open Source and Transparency

At the foundation of this platform lies a commitment to transparency. Every major componentâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrom the algorithm that ranks posts to the data that informs decisionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šshould be open source and publicly auditable. People must be able to see how information moves, how visibility is determined, and how their contributions areÂ valued.

By keeping the code, funding sources, and moderation logic open, the platform earns trust through visibility, not promises. Just as citizens can participate in discussions, they can also participate in improving the system itselfâ€Šâ€”â€Šsubmitting code, suggesting fixes, or analysing biases in realÂ time.

Openness makes corruption harder and collaboration easier. It turns the system into a public good, owned and shaped by the very people itÂ serves.

And importantly, as highlighted by the Association Redefine, open source creates long-term resilience. Even if a project shuts down, communities can continue developing and maintaining the tools because the code belongs to everyone. Investments donâ€™t vanishâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey evolve into a living civic ecosystem that outlives any singleÂ platform

Visualising Data forÂ Clarity

A civic platform can generate thousands of posts, threads, and interactions. To make this complexity understandable, we need simple, smart visualisations that reveal the shape of the conversation at a glance. These visuals help each person see where they stand, how the community thinks, and how decisions evolve.

We focus on five key visualÂ tools:

  1. Profile Map â€”helps you understand how you participate in the civicÂ space.
  2. Press Landscapeâ€Šâ€”â€Šcompares how different media sources frame the sameÂ issue.
  3. Community Landscapeâ€Šâ€”â€Šclusters related discussions to reveal priorities and tensions.
  4. Debate Pathwaysâ€Šâ€”â€Šmaps the flow of arguments from context toÂ risks.
  5. Voting Impact Mapâ€Šâ€”â€Šshows how different votes influence outcomes and eachÂ other.

Profile Map

Inspired by the philosophy behind Readocracy, it doesnâ€™t measure popularity; it measures depth, diversity, and quality of your engagement.

Your Profile Map reflects thingsÂ like:

  • the topics youÂ explore
  • the perspectives youâ€™ve engagedÂ with
  • the clarity and helpfulness of your contributions
  • your willingness to consider alternative views

Over time, the Profile Map becomes a visual record of your learning journeyâ€Šâ€”â€Šshowing how your understanding evolves and where your strengths or blind spots mayÂ lie

Press Landscape Map

Inspired by AllSides and Improve the News, the Press Landscape Map shows how different media outlets frame the same issue. Instead of one narrative, you see a simple side-by-side comparison: what each source highlights, ignores, or emphasises emotionally.

A slider lets you move between left, centre, and right perspectives, revealing coverage gaps and bias patterns instantly. The goal isnâ€™t to tell you what to believe, but to help you see the full information spectrum so you can form your own, well-rounded view.

Community Landscape

Inspired by Polis, the Community Landscape shows where people agree, where they diverge, and where new ideas are emerging. Instead of a chaotic comment feed, opinions are grouped into clusters, making patterns visible at aÂ glance.

You can instantly see:

  • areas of broad consensus
  • viewpoints gainingÂ traction
  • minority positions that addÂ nuance
  • topics that need more voices orÂ clarity

Debate Pathways

Inspired by Kialo, Debate Pathways turns discussions into clear, structured argument maps. Instead of scrolling through emotional, unstructured comments, you follow a simple, logical flow: Context, Problem, Proposed Solution, Supporting Arguments, Counterarguments, Risks and Trade-offs

Each point branches visually, so you can explore an idea from multiple angles without getting lost. This structure helps users see why people disagree, where the strongest reasoning sits, and what blind spotsÂ remain.

Voting ImpactÂ Map

The Voting Impact Map shows how each contribution and engagement shapes real outcomes. Instead of pressing a button blindly, you can see the Immediate effects of each choice and who is positively or negatively affected. You can also spot how this decision connects to other issues and map Potential long-term consequences

Visually, it works like a branching diagram: each voting option expands into predicted impacts, trade-offs, and ripple effects across related topics. This helps citizens understand not only what they are voting for, but what it leadsÂ to.

The goal is to make voting transparent, informed, and interconnectedâ€Šâ€”â€Šturning every choice into a conscious, educated action rather than a guess in theÂ dark.

Closing

Over the past decade, we have watched technology reshape politics in ways both inspiring and alarming. Digital platforms have given millions of people a voice, but they have also enabled manipulation, polarisation, and propaganda at a scale that was once unimaginable. Elections, public opinion, and social movements are now influenced not just by policies and ideas, but by algorithms, recommendation feeds, and data-driven emotional triggers.

If democracy is to survive and evolve, it must adapt to this new reality. And to do that, we must ask a deeper question:

What makes democracy strong in the firstÂ place?

The answer is not just voting, nor simply participating. The answer is truth-seeking.

Democracy is only as strong as the willingness of people to go to the bottom of theÂ â€œtruthâ€.

If citizens donâ€™t question assumptions, investigate claims, or look beyond the most entertaining narrative, democracy becomes vulnerableâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot because people lack intelligence, but because human nature prefers comfort to complexity and there are not plenty of means to doÂ so.

I am proposing a holistic platform that can support civilians to stay active, informed and respectful to their community.

Thank you for reading!
Iâ€™d love to connect and hear your views on how we can create the best possible experience for a platform like this. Your perspective matters.Â LinkedIn

And if you want to support more writing like this, feel free to buy me a coffeeÂ â˜•ğŸ™‚

title: The salt in the AI cake: seven emerging jobs no one is preparing for
text:
The salt in the AI cake: seven emerging jobs no one is preparing for

In the quiet corners of our technological revolution, there is a crisis no one is naming. We are building systems designed to augment human capability whilst simultaneously dismantling the very expertise needed to govern them. This is not a story about job displacement. It is about a category of work we have not yet learnt toÂ value.

The cake you cannotÂ fix

I often explain responsible AI development through baking. If you bake a cake with salt instead of sugar, you cannot fix it afterwards. You have to startÂ over.

The metaphor lands because everyone understands irreversibility. Yet I keep meeting consulting firms and product teams, many in highly regulated sectors, who assume they can retrofit compliance later. Build fast, they say. Worry about transparency and accountability once the systemÂ works.

They cannot.

Most AI applications being developed today, especially those built on opaque foundation models with no visibility on data provenance, bias controls, or training processes, cannot be retrofitted to meet regulatory requirements. The EU AI Act does not allow you to add documentation, traceability, and human oversight as afterthoughts. These must be baked into the architecture from the beginning.

The salt is already in the mixture. Organisations are only just beginning to tasteÂ it.

The crisis in plainÂ sight

Whilst headlines obsess over which jobs AI will eliminate, something more consequential is happening. We are creating an entire ecosystem of AI systems with no one qualified to govern them: a recent study by Fluree shows that the average enterprise runs an 367 (!) SaaS apps, most of which have AI integrated.

The issue isnâ€™t that the technology is ungovernable, itâ€™s that weâ€™re not cultivating the expertise required to do the governing.

Think about what deploying a high-risk AI system actually requires. You need someone who can question whether the training data reflects reality or bias. Someone who can challenge whether the optimisation function aligns with human values. Someone who can monitor whether a model performing at 95% accuracy today has quietly degraded. Someone who can explain to a regulator, or an affected citizen, why the algorithm made the decision itÂ did.

These are not technical problems. They are judgement problems.
And judgement cannot be automated.

Here is the paradox. AI has expertise without context. It can process patterns across vast datasets but cannot understand why or when that knowledge matters. It can identify correlations in historical hiring data but cannot tell you whether those correlations reflect meritocracy or structural discrimination. It can optimise for efficiency but cannot weigh the moral implications of sacrificing fairness to doÂ so.

That gap between machine capability and human judgement is where the most important work of the next decade willÂ happen.

The roles we are notÂ creating

This crisis is not theoretical. It is already creating demand for a new category of roles. Roles that do not just manage AI, but ensure it serves humanÂ values.

Consider what Actor-Network Theory has long taught us. AI systems are not neutral tools. They are embedded in networks of human actors, institutional power structures, regulatory frameworks, and social values. Governing AI is not just about managing algorithms. It is about navigating these complex, interconnected systems.

Seven distinct professional roles are emerging. Not technical positions requiring coding expertise. Knowledge positions requiring deep domain expertise, critical thinking, and systems thinking. The ability to see how changes in one part ripple through theÂ whole.

1. The AI Decision Auditor questions and validates AI before implementation. When a hiring algorithm rejects a candidate, someone must verify the logic was not simply reproducing historical discrimination. When a diagnostic tool recommends treatment, someone must ensure it did not hallucinate a correlation. The AI Actâ€™s Article 14 requires human oversight for high-risk systems, but human oversight without the expertise to question is theatre, not governance.

2. The Human Accountability Architect designs processes that preserve human responsibility even as systems become more autonomous. As multi-agent AI proliferates, accountability becomes genuinely unclear. Someone must ensure that when things fail, and they will, there is an answer to the regulatorâ€™s inevitable question. Who is responsible?

3. The Multimodal Interaction Designer orchestrates how multiple AI agents collaborate with human oversight. Modern systems are ecosystems of agents, interfaces, and decision points that must work coherently. Article 13 requires transparency about how AI systems operate, but transparency means nothing if the experience is incomprehensible.

4. The AI Risk Steward monitors systems for drift, degradation, and bias emergence. AI does not break loudly. It degrades quietly. Someone must watch for the silent erosion before damage compounds.

5. The Responsible AI Implementation Strategist translates between technical teams, who build, and legal teams, who interpret, ensuring compliance is not theatre but embedded practice.

6. The AI Drift and Integrity Analyst tracks model performance over time, identifying when systems produce unreliable results before regulatory audits discover the problem. Article 72â€™s post-market monitoring obligations assume someone is actually monitoring. Most organisations areÂ not.

7. The Transparency and Explainability Designer translates AI decision-making into understandable explanations. Technical accuracy means nothing if humans cannot comprehend it.

This roles are innovative in this form, but not new. For instance, most commercial aircraft have sophisticated autopilot systems. They can handle take-off, maintain altitude, navigate routes, even land in certain conditions. Yet no airline would dream of removing the pilots from the cockpit. No passenger would board a flight knowing there was no one able to take the controls.

Why? Because automation is not the same as autonomy.
Because systems fail in unexpected ways. Because edge cases require human judgement. Because someone must remain responsible.

AI systems are the same. These seven roles are the pilots in the cockpit. They do not fly the plane manually, but they remain essential. Monitoring, overriding when necessary, taking control when the automated systems encounter situations they were not designed toÂ handle.

These roles all require human judgement to check, guide, and refine AI outputs. They cannot be performed by AI itself. That would be asking the algorithm to audit the algorithm.

The illusion of competence

But the crisis runs deeper than a lack of roles. It is also about the erosion of expertise, and the dangerous illusion that anyone can governÂ AI.

Consider the current enthusiasm for vibe coding. The idea that anyone can now build functional applications through natural language prompts, no programming knowledge required.

There is truth here. Barriers have lowered. But there is also a dangerous fallacy. We are conflating the ability to generate code with the expertise to evaluate whether that code is fit forÂ purpose.

What happens when the AI hallucinates? When it generates plausible-looking code with subtle security vulnerabilities? When it optimises for the wrong objective because the prompt was not preciseÂ enough?

The person with no coding expertise cannot spot these failures. They have outsourced not just the manual work of typing code, but the expertise required to recognise when the output isÂ wrong.

We are creating a generation seduced by the illusion of capability without competence.

And what happens when the AI models disappear? Not because of some apocalyptic scenario, but simply because a service shuts down, a company pivots, a model becomes obsolete. If we have outsourced expertise to systems we do not understand, what knowledge remains?

Our wetware, our brain, our lived experience, our ability to connect and contextualise knowledge, this is what makes us uniquely suited to ask the right questions for any given situation.

That cannot be delegated. It can only be cultivated.

Two hundred and fiftyÂ files

Now let me tell you something that should keep every AI executive awake atÂ night.

Recent research by Anthropic, in partnership with the UK AI Safety Institute and the Alan Turing Institute, revealed that just 250 malicious files can compromise even the largest language models. A fraction so small, roughly 0.00016% of the training data, that it is effectively a roundingÂ error.

Models ranging from 600 million to 13 billion parameters, systems trained on datasets so vast they would take human lifetimes to read, can be poisoned by a rounding errorâ€™s worth of corrupted data.

Data poisoning works by injecting malicious inputs, often indistinguishable from legitimate data, into a modelâ€™s training set. These inputs create hidden vulnerabilities like backdoors or biased outputs that only activate under specific conditions. A model might perform perfectly during testing, only to produce harmful outputs when it encounters a particular trigger phrase in production. Because the poisoning is subtle and the training datasets are vast, it evades detection until it is too late. By the time you discover the problem, the corruption is already baked into the modelâ€™sÂ weights.

The assumption that bigger model equals safer model has collapsed.

And data poisoning is already happening. Adversarial actors are already exploiting these weaknesses. And most organisations deploying AI systems have no idea whether their training data has been compromised.

For every interface your design team polishes, for every user experience your product team optimises, there is an invisible substrate of risk embedded in the data that feeds your AI. You can make the chatbot delightful. You cannot make it trustworthy if the foundation is poisoned.

Training data hygiene matters far more than sheer computational scale. You can have billions of parameters and state-of-the-art architecture, but if 250 malicious documents made it into your training pipeline, you have built an expensive liability.

And here is what makes this discovery so devastating for the retrofit compliance later crowd. You cannot audit what you cannot see. You cannot fix what was baked into the modelâ€™s weights during training.

The salt is in the mixture. No amount of post-hoc filtering will extractÂ it.

This is precisely why the seven roles I have outlined are not optional enhancements. They are the minimum viable governance for responsible deployment. The AI Decision Auditor who can question whether an unexpected output reflects genuine intelligence or a dormant trigger phrase. The Human Accountability Architect who ensures someone can be held responsible when a poisoned model makes harmful decisions. The AI Risk Steward who monitors for the subtle drift that signals data degradation.

Without these capabilities, you are deploying systems you cannot trust and defending against threats you cannotÂ see.

Trust, in this context, is earned through design, not assumed byÂ default.

The investment we are notÂ making

Yet here is the reality. We are not investing in the next generation who will fill these custodial roles.

Organisations hesitate to hire junior staff because they expect roles to change. But that is precisely why we need them. What makes junior roles sustainable is not teaching people to use todayâ€™s tools. It is giving them solid theoretical and analytical grounding so they can adapt as tools evolve, challenge AI outputs with informed scepticism, and bring human judgement into the collaboration.

And universities? They are still teaching AI ethics as an elective, not a core competency. The ability to audit an algorithm for bias or design an accountability framework should be as fundamental as calculus for engineers, as essential as anatomy for doctors. Or we risk graduating a generation of builders with no guardians.
Instead, we are still producing graduates who can train neural networks but cannot explain why a modelâ€™s accuracy dropped, or what fair even means in the context of algorithmic decision-making.

They certainly cannot identify the signs of data poisoning before it is too late.
Schools must treat AI governance as a core competency, not an afterthought. Courses shouldÂ cover:

  • How to challenge algorithms, not just build them. Questioning the assumptions embedded in training data and optimisation functions. Understanding when correlation is not causation, when efficiency creates injustice, when accuracy masksÂ harm.
  • How to design accountability frameworks for sociotechnical systems. Grounded in both regulatory requirements like the AI Act and human-centred design principles. Students should graduate knowing how to trace decisions through complex systems, how to preserve human responsibility even as automation proliferates.
  • Ethics and scenario modelling as core competencies. The ability to anticipate second-order effects and unintended consequences. To ask not just â€œcan we build this?â€ but â€œshould we?â€ and â€œwhat happens when thisÂ fails?â€
  • The distinction between legal compliance and moral responsibility. Between what systems can do and what they should do. Between meeting the letter of regulation and honouring the spirit of humanÂ dignity.
  • Systems thinking that recognises AI as part of complex networks. Involving human actors, institutional structures, and social contexts. How to conduct adversarial thinking, imagining how systems might be exploited and building defences before vulnerabilities are discovered in production.
  • Provenance tracking and dataset auditing as foundational skills. Not specialised techniques reserved for security teams, but basic competencies for anyone working with AI. If you cannot trace where your training data came from, you cannot trust what your model produces.

Sociotechnical systems theory reminds us that every technological system is also a social system. Shaped by power, policy, and human judgement. Building AI without recognising this is not innovation. It isÂ amnesia.

What makes us irreplaceable

Historically, physical labour gave way to intellectual work. Intellectual work is now giving way to oversight and accountability. We are becoming the moral anchors of a machine-operated world.

This pattern is not new. Every technological revolution creates categories of work that did not exist before. Not by eliminating human contribution, but by redefining what makes that contribution irreplaceable.

Consider Mary Smith, the knocker-upper who woke factory workers each morning. The alarm clock eliminated her profession. But it did not eliminate the need for humans in the morning economy. It simply shifted where human judgement mattered.

AI is following the same path. Machines make outputs. Humans must own outcomes.

That is not poetic language. It is the legal and ethical line the AI ActÂ draws.

The question is not whether these roles will exist. They are already emerging, driven by regulatory pressure, operational necessity, and the simple reality that 250 poisoned files can compromise billions of parameters.

The question is whether we will invest in developing the expertise to fill them before systems fail, reputations collapse, or regulators intervene.

The choice beforeÂ us

So here we stand, at the intersection of human intelligence and artificial systems, facing a choice that organisations have not yet recognised asÂ urgent.

Build responsible AI from the ground up, or waste resources building systems that cannot comply with regulation and cannot be trusted with high-stakes decisions. Cultivate the next generation of AI custodians, or outsource our collective future to algorithms with no one qualified to questionÂ them.

The future of responsible AI is not technical. It isÂ human.

It requires investing in roles that blend deep domain expertise with critical thinking. It requires recognising that governance is not overhead but foundation. It requires remembering what centuries of technological evolution have demonstrated. Machines amplify human choices. They do not render those choices irrelevant. They make them more consequential thanÂ ever.

True innovation requires more than computational power. It demandsÂ wisdom.

Where toÂ start?

If you are leading an organisation deploying AI systems, ask yourself these questions.

  • Who in your organisation can challenge an algorithmâ€™s reasoning before it affects real people? Not describe how it works technically, but question whether it should work that way atÂ all.
  • Who is responsible when your AI system degrades and no one notices until the damage compounds?
  • Who will explain to a regulator, or to a person denied credit, employment, or healthcare, why the algorithm made the decision itÂ did?
  • Who can identify whether 250 malicious files have compromised your training data before you have deployed a billion-parameter liability into production?

If you cannot answer these questions with names and capabilities, you do not have an AI strategy. You have an AI experiment unfolding in production with no one steeringÂ it.

The seven roles outlined here are not future speculation. The AI Act has made them mandatory for high-risk systems. Market reality is making them essential for competitive advantage. And the simple mathematical fact that 0.00016% contamination can compromise the largest models has made them existentially urgent.

The salt is in the mixture. The only question remaining is whether you will recognise it before you serve the cake, or after your customers tasteÂ it.

The guardians weÂ choose

The future of AI is not just about what machines can do. It is about what humans must become. The custodians of context. The challengers of logic. The guardians of outcomes.

Every algorithm carries within it the echoes of human decision-making. Our challenge is not to fear these technologies, but to consciously shape their ethical foundations. To invest in the people capable of doing thatÂ shaping.

If your organisation is not creating these roles today, you are not just falling behind. You are building a ticking time bomb. Because when systems fail, and they will, no one will ask what the algorithm decided. They will ask who was responsible for letting itÂ decide.

The question is not whether you can afford to create these positions.

It is whether you can afford notÂ to.

Consider the alarm clock that replaced Mary Smithâ€™s profession. Not just a technological replacement, but a metaphor for human adaptability. Each technological shift does not eliminate human potential. It reshapesÂ it.

Our deepest innovations emerge not from machines, but from the human capacity to reimagine possibility.

The future of AI will not belong to the coders alone.
It will belong to the guardians we choose toÂ train.
